text: a desperate call to the emergency
services as a deadly tide of mud and
rock crushed everything in its path
houses were swept off their foundations
trees keeled over and people were sucked
into the sea of mud like quicksand
we were tumbled inside and had mud in
our eyes and nose and mouth and I'm
really grateful I'm alive from the air
it's possible to see the scale of the
disaster weeks of unusually heavy rain
had softened the ground then without
warning a slice of the hillside
collapsed into the river valley
there were frantic efforts to dig people
out of the mud one local resident Shawn
Wright heard screams and ran over to
find a baby and his mother buried
beneath the debris he used chainsaws to
get them out alive where we got her was
just a breather you couldn't tell
anything with houses it was just all
debris when help arrived many used dogs
others took to boats and even a
hovercraft it was dangerous work
some rescuers got stuck in the mud
themselves and had to be pulled out Oso
was a quiet community of a hundred and
eighty people but it didn't stand a
chance when a wall of mud 1500 feet wide
and 600 feet high crashed down on top of
it the rescue work goes on but hopes for
survivors are fading no one has been
found alive since Saturday Emily
Buchanan BBC news
